form.preferredDefinition: The National Institute of Mental Health (NIMH) Sleep Patterns and Problems instrument is an interviewer-administered questionnaire which captures routine sleep schedule, sleep deprivation, morningness-eveningness, insomnia, narcolepsy, cataplexy and associated distress.

headerInstruction.text: I am now going to ask you about your usual sleep patterns.

question.questionText: INTERVIEWER: Please tell participant that they should not reveal their diagnosis to you. (instr2_0121001)

Do you normally work (or attend school) during the day and sleep at night? INTERVIEWER: If individual is unemployed and out of school, ask about his/her usual time of activity instead. (work_during_day)
What is your normal work (or school) and sleep schedule? (normal_schedule)

validValue.meaningText: Always works nights, sleeps during the day
validValue.description: Always works nights, sleeps during the day

question.questionText: What is your normal work (or school) and sleep schedule? Other, Describe (normal_schedule_other_describe)
What shift schedule do you most often work? (which_shift)
What shift schedule do you most often work? (Other): (shift_other_121001)
At what time do you usually go to bed: On a workday or school day? (bedtime_workday)
AM or PM (bedtime_workday_am_pm)
At what time do you usually go to bed: On a nonwork or nonschool day (i.e., weekend)? (bedtime_nonwork_day)
AM or PM (bedtime_nonwork_day_am_pm)
About how many minutes does it usually take for you to fall asleep: On a workday or school day? (fall_asleep_workday)
About how many minutes does it usually take for you to fall asleep: On a nonwork or nonschool day (i.e., weekend)? (fall_asleep_nonworkday)
At what time do you usually wake up: On a workday or school day? (wake_up_workday)
AM or PM (wake_up_workday_am_pm)
At what time do you usually wake up:On a nonwork or nonschool day (i.e., weekend)? (wake_up_nonworkday)
AM or PM (wake_up_nonworkday_am_pm)
How long does it take for you to become fully awake from regular sleep (i.e., after first opening your eyes in the morning)? (time_to_wake_up_minutes)
How long does it take for you to become fully awake from regular sleep (i.e., after first opening your eyes in the morning)? (time_to_wake_up_hours)
Do you use an alarm clock to wake up in the morning? (alarm_clock)
Do you have great difficulty waking up in the morning? (difficulty_waking_up)
Do you often have so much trouble waking up that an alarm clock won't wake you and you have to use other methods to wake up? (methods_besides_alarm)
Describe (methods_besides_alarm_describe)
When you wake up in the morning or from a nap, do you feel "out of it" and "confused"? (waking_up_confused)
How long does it take for you to fully awaken? (Minutes) (fully_awaken_nap_minutes)
How long does it take for you to fully awaken? (Hours) (fully_awaken_nap_hours)
How much sleep do you usually get during a typical night: On a workday or school day? (amount_sleep_workday_minutes)
How much sleep do you usually get during a typical night: On a workday or school day? (amount_sleep_workday_hours)
How much sleep do you usually get during a typical night: On a nonwork or nonschool day (i.e., weekend)? (amount_sleep_nonworkday_minutes)
How much sleep do you usually get during a typical night: On a nonwork or nonschool day (i.e., weekend)? (amount_sleep_nonworkday_hours)

Do you usually follow the same sleep schedule (i.e., no more than a 1 hour difference in sleep and wake times) on both work/school and nonwork/school days? (or school days and weekends) (follow_same_sleep_schedule)
How many hours of sleep per night do you think you need to feel fully rested the next day? (hours_sleep_needed)
Do you feel awake and refreshed after sleeping? (feel_refreshed)
How often do you remember your dreams? That is, dreams that occur during your regular sleep and not while napping (remember_dreams)
How often do you take naps? (how_often_take_naps)
At what time(s) of the day do you usually take naps? INTERVIEWER: List up to 3 time(s) of the day. (naptime1)
AM or PM (naptime1_am_pm)
At what time(s) of the day do you usually take naps? (naptime2)
AM or PM (naptime2_am_pm)
At what time(s) of the day do you usually take naps? (naptime3)
AM or PM (naptime3_am_pm)
How many hours and minutes of sleep do you usually get when you take a nap? (amount_sleep_naptime_minutes)

instruction.text: datatype=number;[how_often_take_naps] = '1' and [how_often_take_naps] = '2' and [how_often_take_naps] = '3' and [how_often_take_naps] = '4' and [how_often_take_naps] = '9'; UOM=minute

question.questionText: How many hours and minutes of sleep do you usually get when you take a nap? (amount_sleep_naptime_hours)

instruction.text: datatype=number;[how_often_take_naps] = '1' and [how_often_take_naps] = '2' and [how_often_take_naps] = '3' and [how_often_take_naps] = '4' and [how_often_take_naps] = '9'; UOM=hour

question.questionText: Do you have great difficulty waking up from naps? (difficulty_waking_from_naps)
How often do you dream when you nap? (dream_nap)
Are these dreams very intense, detailed and vivid, like watching a movie? (nap_dreams_intense)
How difficult is it for you to adapt to a sleep loss of 3 hours or more (i.e. sleeping 3 or more hours less than you normally do the night before)? (adapt_sleep_loss_3hours)

INTERVIEWER: For the questions below, first determine whether sleep loss affects these factors. If there is a change following sleep loss,select whether there is an improvement or a worsening, or an increase or decrease. (inst8_0121001)
Does this loss of sleep affect you the next day with respect to. your mood (being sadder or happier)? (sleep_loss_affect_mood)
Does this loss of sleep affect you the next day with respect to. your mood (being sadder or happier)? (sleep_loss_affect_mood_how)
Does this loss of sleep affect you the next day with respect to.your tendency to be irritable? (sleep_loss_affect_irritable)
Does this loss of sleep affect you the next day with respect to. your tendency to be irritable? (If yes, How?) (sleep_loss_affect_irritable_how)
Does this loss of sleep affect you the next day with respect to your ability to get your work done? (sleep_loss_affect_work)
Does this loss of sleep affect you the next day with respect to...? your ability to get your work done? (If yes, How?) (sleep_loss_affect_work_how)
Does this loss of sleep affect you the next day with respect to how much you eat? (sleep_loss_affect_eating)
Does this loss of sleep affect you the next day with respect to how much you eat? (If yes, How?) (sleep_loss_affect_eating_how)
Does this loss of sleep affect you the next day with respect to your desire for chocolate or sweets? (sleep_loss_affect_eating_sweets)
Does this loss of sleep affect you the next day with respect to your desire for chocolate or sweets? (If yes, How?) (sleep_loss_affect_eatingsweets_how)
How quickly after this loss of sleep, do you return to your usual self if you are allowed to sleep as much as you like? (loss_of_sleep_recovery)
Do you prefer to keep a regular sleep schedule (i.e. one that does not change much from one night to the next)? (prefer_regular_sleep_schedule)
If you do not keep your regular sleep schedule, how much do you feel off (i.e. not your regular self) the next day?" (no_sleep_schedule_feel_off)
When you are traveling EAST by air and you cross over several time zones, how quickly do you return to your usual sleeping pattern (jet_lag_east)
What about when you are traveling WEST by air over several time zones? (jet_lag_west)
Do you consider yourself to be a morning person (early bird) an evening person (night owl) or neither? (morning_or_evening_person)
How strong is your preference? (morning_evening_preference)

INTERVIEWER: Does respondent consistently fall asleep very late (i.e., 12 a.m. or later) at night AND characterize him/herself as a night owl" with a "strong preference"?" (interviewer_morning_evening)

When you do not have to maintain a strict schedule (i.e. not dictated by strict work or school schedules, as while on vacation or not working): ...at what time do you usually go to sleep (i.e. feel sleepy and ready to go to bed)? (sleep_time_vacation)
AM or PM (sleep_time_vacation_am_pm)

When you do not have to maintain a strict schedule (i.e. not dictated by strict work or school schedules, as while on vacation or not working): ...at what time do you usually wake up (wake_time_vacation)
AM or PM (wake_time_vacation_am_pm)

When you do not have to maintain a strict schedule (i.e. not dictated by strict work or school schedules, as while on vacation or not working): ...are these usual sleep and wake times always about the same (i.e. each day during a week of vacation)? (similar_wake_sleep_times_vacation)

When you do not have to maintain a strict schedule (i.e. not dictated by strict work or school schedules, as while on vacation or not working): ...do you wake up on your own (i.e., without an alarm or other assistance)? (wake_on_own_vacation)
Have you ever tried to force yourself to fall asleep at an (earlier) time than your usual bedtime? (force_self_asleep_early)
When you tried to shift your sleep schedule to an earlier bedtime (at least 1 to 2 hours earlier), did you have difficulty falling asleep (force_self_asleep_early_difficulty)
Do attempts to change your sleep/wake schedule tend to make your sleeping difficulties worse? (changing_schedules_sleep_more_difficult)
During the past year, what was the longest period of time that you had these sleeping problems on most nights? (last_year_longest_period_weeks)
During the past year, what was the longest period of time that you had these sleeping problems on most nights? (last_year_longest_period_months)
During the past year, what was the longest period of time that you had these sleeping problems on most nights? (last_year_longest_period_years)
How old were you when you first began going to sleep very late without being able to adjust your schedule when you tried? (age_sleep_without_adjusting_schedule)
How old were you the last time you experienced these problems? (age_last_episode)
Do you currently experience these problems? (currently_experience_problems)

instruction.text: Please look at this scale from 0 to 10, where 0 means no distress/impairment and 10 means very severe problems.

question.questionText: Please look at this scale from 0 to 10, where 0 means no distress/impairment and 10 means very severe problems. (instr8_0121001)
How much have your late bedtime and inability to adjust your schedule upset or distressed you? (distressed_scale)
What number describes how much this eveningness tendency has affected your social life and/or relationships with your friends? (social_distress_scale)
What number describes how much this eveningness tendency has affected your relationships with family members? (relationship_distress_scale)

What number describes how much this eveningness tendency has affected your performance in school/work or your relationships with your coworkers, employers, teachers or classmates? (work_distress_scale)
Have you ever had frequent problems getting to sleep at the beginning of the night which has negatively affected how you function during the following day? (getting_to_sleep_work_problems)
Have you ever had frequent problems staying asleep at night which has negatively affected how you function during the following day? (staying_asleep_work_problems)

Have you ever had frequent problems falling back to sleep after waking in the middle of the nigh which has negatively affected how you function during the following day? (falling_back_asleep_work_problems)
In the past year, have you had difficulty getting to sleep? (past_year_difficulty_falling_asleep)
In the past year, have you awakened during the night and had a hard time getting back to sleep? (past_year_awakened_middle_night)
In the past year, have you awakened too early in the morning and couldn't get back to sleep? (past_year_wake_up_early)
What was the longest period of time you had sleeping problems (such as those described above) on most nights during the past year? (weeks) (past_year_longest_period_weeks)
What was the longest period of time you had sleeping problems (such as those described above) on most nights during the past year? (months) (past_year_longest_period_months)
What was the longest period of time you had sleeping problems (such as those described above) on most nights during the past year?(years) (past_year_longest_period_years)
INTERVIEWER: If respondent endorses less than one month of sleeping problems, SKIP to NarcolepsyCataplexy section. (inst9_0121001)

Do you experience any of the following during the daytime due to your difficulties falling asleep or staying asleep at night: Attention, concentration or memory problems? (difficulty_attention_concentration)

Do you experience any of the following during the daytime due to your difficulties falling asleep or staying asleep at night: Errors or accidents at work or while driving? (difficulty_errors_accidents)
Do you experience any of the following during the daytime due to your difficulties falling asleep or staying asleep at night: Social problems or poor work/school performance? (difficulty_social_work)
Do you experience any of the following during the daytime due to your difficulties falling asleep or staying asleep at night: Fatigue? (difficulty_fatigue)
Do you experience any of the following during the daytime due to your difficulties falling asleep or staying asleep at night: Sleepiness? (difficulty_sleepiness)
Do you experience any of the following during the daytime due to your difficulties falling asleep or staying asleep at night: Feeling tense/muscle tension? (difficulty_tense)
Do you experience any of the following during the daytime due to your difficulties falling asleep or staying asleep at night: Headaches? (difficulty_headaches)

Do you experience any of the following during the daytime due to your difficulties falling asleep or staying asleep at night: Gastrointestinal symptoms (e.g. upset stomach, nervous stomach)? (difficulty_gastrointestinal)
Do you experience any of the following during the daytime due to your difficulties falling asleep or staying asleep at night: Mood changes/problems or irritability? (difficulty_mood)

Do you experience any of the following during the daytime due to your difficulties falling asleep or staying asleep at night: A lack of motivation or energy to do things (manifested as e.g. procrastination or lack of initiative)? (difficulty_motivation)
Do you experience any of the following during the daytime due to your difficulties falling asleep or staying asleep at night: Concerns or worries about sleep? (difficulties_worried_about_sleep)
Do you do any of the following during the night when you cannot fall asleep, do you: Experience frustration, tension and/or anxiety over not being able to go to sleep? (difficulty_anxiety)
Do you do any of the following during the night when you cannot fall asleep, do you: Look at the clock frequently to see how long you have not been able to fall asleep? (look_at_clock)

When you are NOT sleeping in your usual bed (e.g. in a hotel room while on vacation, or on your couch watching television), do you still have problems initially getting to sleep, staying asleep, or falling back to sleep after waking up during the night? (unusual_bed_difficulty)

Does your difficulty with insomnia occur at the same time as any of the following events or conditions (i.e. is the insomnia associated temporally with any of the following)? ...caffeine or other stimulant use? (caffeine)

Does your difficulty with insomnia occur at the same time as any of the following events or conditions (i.e. is the insomnia associated temporally with any of the following)? ...other drugs or medications? (other_drugs)
Specify (other_drugs_specify)

Does your difficulty with insomnia occur at the same time as any of the following events or conditions (i.e. is the insomnia associated temporally with any of the following? ...changing schedule? (changing_schedule)
Specify (changing_schedule_specify)

Does your difficulty with insomnia occur at the same time as any of the following events or conditions (i.e. is the insomnia associated temporally with any of the following)? ...noisy or uncomfortable surroundings? (noisy_surroundings)
Specify (noisy_surroundings_specify)

Does your difficulty with insomnia occur at the same time as any of the following events or conditions (i.e. is the insomnia associated temporally with any of the following)? ...stress or major life event? (stress_major_life_event)
Specify (stress_major_life_event_specify)

Does your difficulty with insomnia occur at the same time as any of the following events or conditions (i.e. is the insomnia associated temporally with any of the following)? ...other disturbances (i.e. children, pets, etc.)? (other_disturbances)
Specify (other_disturbances_specify)

Does your difficulty with insomnia occur at the same time as any of the following events or conditions (i.e. is the insomnia associated temporally with any of the following)? ...an emotional or mental condition? (emotional_condition)
Specify (emotional_condition_specify)

Does your difficulty with insomnia occur at the same time as any of the following events or conditions (i.e. is the insomnia associated temporally with any of the following)? ...other medical condition? (other_medical_condition)
Specify (other_medical_condition_specify)
Do you ever have trouble falling asleep or staying asleep, when there seems to be no cause or explanation for it? (no_explanation)
Specify (no_explanation_specify)
Has your difficulty with sleeping occurred or worsened during any of the following conditions... pregnancy? (pregnancy)
Has your difficulty with sleeping occurred or worsened during any of the following conditions... menopause? (ask for women over 35) (menopause)
Has your difficulty with sleeping occurred or worsened during any of the following conditions... just before (a few days) menstruation? (before_menstruation)
Has your difficulty with sleeping occurred or worsened during any of the following conditions... menstruation? (during_menstruation)

How many separate times in your life have you had difficulty getting to sleep, staying asleep or falling back to sleep after waking up during the night (for at least one month)? (number_times_experience_difficulty)
How old were you when you first experienced this kind of difficulty with sleeping (for at least one month)? (age_first_experience_difficulty_month)
How old were you the last time you experienced this insomnia (for at least one month)? (age_last_experience_difficulty_month)
Do you currently experience insomnia? (current_insomnia)
How frequently do you experience insomnia? (Times per week) (insomnia_frequency)

instruction.text: Please look at this scale from 0 to 10, where 0 means no distress/impairment and 10 means very severe problems.

question.questionText: Please look at this scale from 0 to 10, where 0 means no distress/impairment and 10 means very severe problems. (inst6_0121001)
How much does your insomnia (sleep difficulties) upset or distress you? (insomnia_distress_scale)
What number describes how much your insomnia has affected your social life or relationships with your friends? (insomnia_social_impairment_scale)
What number describes how much your insomnia has affected your relationships with family members? (insomnia_family_impairment_scale)

What number describes how much your insomnia has affected your performance in school/work or your relationships with your coworkers, employers, teachers or classmates? (insomnia_work_impairment_scale)
A. Daytime Sleepiness (instr7_0121001)

Do you feel so sleepy during the day that it interrupts your normal activities such as driving, reading, or concentrating at work or school, even when you have had enough sleep the night before? (sleepy_interrupt_day)
How often do you feel this way? (Times per Day) (how_often_interrupt_days)
How often do you feel this way? (Times per Week) (how_often_interrupt_weeks)
How often do you feel this way? (Times per Month) (how_often_interrupt_months)
What is the longest period of time that you have felt this way (on most days)? (longest_period_weeks_interrupt)
What is the longest period of time that you have felt this way (on most days)? (longest_period_months_interrupt)
What is the longest period of time that you have felt this way (on most days)? (longest_period_years_interrupt)
During the daytime, do you experience an overwhelming desire to go to sleep so overwhelming that you cannot resist? (daytime_desire_to_sleep)
How often does this overwhelming desire to go to sleep occur? (Times per Day) (howoften_desire_to_sleep_days)
How often does this overwhelming desire to go to sleep occur? (Times per Week) (howoften_desire_to_sleep_weeks)
How often does this overwhelming desire to go to sleep occur? (Times per Month) (howoften_desire_to_sleep_months)
What is the longest period of time that you have felt this way (on most days)? (longestperiod_desire_to_sleep_weeks)
What is the longest period of time that you have felt this way (on most days)? (longestperiod_desire_to_sleep_months)
What is the longest period of time that you have felt this way (on most days)? (longestperiod_desire_to_sleep_years)
When you do doze off during the day and take a nap, do you find this sleep refreshing? (nap_refreshing)
When you do doze off during the day and take a nap, do you find this sleep refreshing? Describe (nap_refreshing_describe)
Do you feel that you are sleepier than other people your age? (sleepier_than_others)
B. Cataplexy (inst7_0121001)

Do you ever experience periods of muscle weakness, loss of muscle strength or limp muscles in any part of your body (e.g. in the legs or face) during the following situations: ...when you laugh? (muscle_weakness_laugh)

Do you ever experience periods of muscle weakness, loss of muscle strength or limp muscles in any part of your body (e.g. in the legs or face) during the following situations: ...when you are angry? (muscle_weakness_angry)

Do you ever experience periods of muscle weakness, loss of muscle strength or limp muscles in any part of your body (e.g. in the legs or face) during the following situations: ...when you hear or tell a joke? (muscle_weakness_joke)
Have you ever been told that you act out" your dreams?" (act_out_dreams)
How often does this happen (weeks)? (act_out_dreams_howoften_weeks)
How often does this happen (months)? (act_out_dreams_howoften_months)
How often does this happen (years)? (act_out_dreams_howoften_years)
Do you ever move so much during your sleep that you accidentally hit your bed partner (if any) or hurt yourself? (move_in_sleep)
Do you have any memory of these event(s)? (memory_move_in_sleep)
Does moving at night disrupt your sleep? (i.e. wake you up at night) (moving_disrupt_sleep)
During what part of the night do these events most often occur (move_which_half_of_night)

protocol.preferredDefinition: The National Institute of Mental Health (NIMH) Sleep Patterns and Problems instrument is an interviewer-administered questionnaire which captures routine sleep schedule, sleep deprivation, morningness-eveningness, insomnia, narcolepsy, cataplexy and associated distress.

form.preferredDefinition: The Big Five Inventory (BFI) is a self administered, 44 question instrument designed to measure the big five dimensions of personality - extraversion, agreeableness, conscientiousness, neuroticism and openness/intellect.

headerInstruction.text: The following statements concern your perception about yourself in a variety of situations. Your task is to indicate the strength of your agreement with each statement, utilizing a scale in which 1 denotes strong disagreement, 5 denotes strong..TRUNCATED

module.longName: I see myself as someone who...
module.preferredDefinition: I see myself as someone who...

question.questionText: 1. Is talkative (talkative)
2. Tends to find fault with others (finds_fault)
3. Does a thorough job (thorough_job)
4. Is depressed, blue (depressed)
5. Is original, comes up with new ideas (original)
6. Is reserved (reserved)
7. Is helpful and unselfish with others (helpful)
8. Can be somewhat careless (somewhat_careless)
9. Is relaxed, handles stress well (relaxed)
10. Is curious about many different things (curious)
11. Is full of energy (energetic)
12. Starts quarrels with others (starts_quarrels)
13. Is a reliable worker (reliable_worker)
14. Can be tense (tense)
15. Is ingenious, a deep thinker (ingenious)
16. Generates a lot of enthusiasm (generates_enthusiasm)
17. Has a forgiving nature (forgiving)
18. Tends to be disorganized (disorganized)
19. Worries a lot (worries)
20. Has an active imagination (active_imagination)
21. Tends to be quiet (pxt121101_quiet)
22. Is generally trusting (trusting)
23. Tends to be lazy (lazy)
24. Is emotionally stable, not easily upset (emotionally_stable)
25. Is inventive (inventive)
26. Has an assertive personality (assertive)
27. Can be cold and aloof (aloof)
28. Perseveres until the task is finished (persevere)
29. Can be moody (moody)
30. Values artistic, aesthetic experiences (artistic_experiences)
31. Is sometimes shy, inhibited (shy_inhibited)
32. Is considerate, kind to almost everyone (considerate)
33. Does things efficiently (efficient)
34. Remains calm in tense situations (remains_calm)
35. Prefers work that is routine (prefers_routine)
36. Is outgoing, sociable (outgoing)
37. Is sometimes rude to others (rude_to_others)
38. Makes plans and follows through on them (follows_through_on_plans)
39. Gets nervous easily (gets_nervous)
40. Likes to reflect, play with ideas (reflective)
41. Has few artistic interests (few_artistic_interests)
42. Likes to cooperate with others (cooperates_with_others)
43. Is easily distracted (easily_distracted)
44. Is sophisticated in art, music or literature (sophisticated_art_music_literature)

instruction.text: Reversescore the following items: Extraversion: 6, 21, 31Agreeableness: 2, 12, 27, 37Conscientiousness: 8, 18, 23, 43 Neuroticism: 9, 24, 34 Openness: 35, 41 Next, create scale scores for each domain by averaging the following items (where R indicates using the reversescored item). Extraversion: 1, 6R 11, 16, 21R, 26, 31R, 36 Agreeableness: 2R, 7, 12R, 17, 22, 27R, 32, 37R Conscientiousness: 3, 8R, 13, 18R, 23R, 28, 33, 38, 43R Neuroticism: 4, 9R, 14, 19, 24R, 29, 34R, 39 Openness: 5, 10, 15, 20, 25, 30, 35R, 40, 41R, 44 Optional items: Liking: 45, 46

question.questionText: Reversescore the following items: Extraversion: 6, 21, 31Agreeableness: 2, 12, 27, 37Conscientiousness: 8, 18, 23, 43 Neuroticism: 9, 24, 34 Openness: 35, 41 Next, create scale scores for each domain by averaging the following items (where R indicates using the reversescored item). Extraversion: 1, 6R 11, 16, 21R, 26, 31R, 36 Agreeableness: 2R, 7, 12R, 17, 22, 27R, 32, 37R Conscientiousness: 3, 8R, 13, 18R, 23R, 28, 33, 38, 43R Neuroticism: 4, 9R, 14, 19, 24R, 29, 34R, 39 Openness: 5, 10, 15, 20, 25, 30, 35R, 40, 41R, 44 Optional items: Liking: 45, 46 (scoringinst_0121101)

protocol.preferredDefinition: The Big Five Inventory (BFI) is a self administered, 44 question instrument designed to measure the big five dimensions of personality - extraversion, agreeableness, conscientiousness, neuroticism and openness/intellect.

form.preferredDefinition: The K6 is a screening scale consisting of 6 questions to assess nonspecific psychological distress during the last 30 days. These questions ask about the respondent's feelings and how these feelings have affected their normal activities, and whether or not they have sought professional help.

headerInstruction.text: The following questions ask about how you have been feeling during the past 30 days. For each question, please indicate the answer that best describes how often you had this feeling.

question.questionText: 1.a During the past 30 days, about how often did you feel... nervous? (nervous)
1.b During the past 30 days, about how often did you feel... hopeless ? (hopeless)
1.c During the past 30 days, about how often did you feel... restless or fidgety? (pxt121301_restless)
1.d During the past 30 days, about how often did you feel... so depressed that nothing could cheer you up? (pxt121301_depressed)
1. e During the past 30 days, about how often did you feel... that everything was an effort? (everything_an_effort)
1.f During the past 30 days, about how often did you feel... worthless? (worthless)

2. The last six questions asked about feelings that might have occurred during the past 30 days. Taking them altogether, did these feelings occur more often in the past 30 days than is usual for you, about the same as usual, or less often than usual? (If you never have any of these feelings, circle response option 4.")" (frequency_feelings_past_thirty_days)
3. During the past 30 days, how many days out of 30 were you totally unable to work or carry out your normal activities because of these feelings? (number_days_worked)

instruction.text: datatype=number;[nervous] = '1' or [nervous] = '2' or [nervous] = '3' or [nervous] = '4' or [hopeless] = '2' or [hopeless] = '2' or [hopeless] = '3' or [hopeless] = '4' or [pxt121301_restless] = '1' or [pxt121301_restless] = '2' or [pxt121301_restless] = '3' ..TRUNCATED; UOM=day

question.questionText: 4. Not counting the days you reported in response to 3, how many days in the past 30 were you able to do only half or less of what you would normally have been able to do, because of these feelings? (number_days_do_only_half)

instruction.text: datatype=number;[nervous] = '1' or [nervous] = '2' or [nervous] = '3' or [nervous] = '4' or [hopeless] = '2' or [hopeless] = '2' or [hopeless] = '3' or [hopeless] = '4' or [pxt121301_restless] = '1' or [pxt121301_restless] = '2' or [pxt121301_restless] = '3' ..TRUNCATED; UOM=day

question.questionText: 5. During the past 30 days, how many times did you see a doctor or other health professional about these feelings? (number_times_see_doctor)

instruction.text: datatype=number;[nervous] = '1' or [nervous] = '2' or [nervous] = '3' or [nervous] = '4' or [hopeless] = '2' or [hopeless] = '2' or [hopeless] = '3' or [hopeless] = '4' or [pxt121301_restless] = '1' or [pxt121301_restless] = '2' or [pxt121301_restless] = '3' ..TRUNCATED

question.questionText: 6. During the past 30 days, how often have physical health problems been the main cause of these feelings? (physical_health_cause_problems)

Code question 1.a through 1.f 04 and sum to convert the K6 to a 024 scale. A cut point of 13 or greater is recommended to assess the prevalence of SMI (serious mental illness). Please see Kessler et al. (2002) for further information on scoring the K6.

question.questionText: Code question 1.a through 1.f 04 and sum to convert the K6 to a 024 scale. A cut point of 13 or greater is recommended to assess the prevalence of SMI (serious mental illness). Please see Kessler et al. (2002) for further information on scoring the K6. (scoring_0121301)

protocol.preferredDefinition: The K6 is a screening scale consisting of 6 questions to assess nonspecific psychological distress during the last 30 days. These questions ask about the respondent's feelings and how these feelings have affected their normal activities, and whether or not they have sought professional help.

form.longName: PhenX PX121401 - Posttraumatic Stress Disorder Ptsd
form.preferredDefinition: The Diagnostic Interview for Genetic Studies (DIGS) Posttraumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) Screener is a 20-question, interviewer-administered questionnaire designed to screen for symptoms of Posttraumatic Stress Disorder. This instrument was adapted from the Genetics of Recurrent Early-Onset Depression (GenRED) research study.

question.questionText: 1. Have you ever experienced, witnessed, or otherwise been involved in any events that could have brought serious harm or even death to you or someone else? (experienced_harmful_events)

1.a. Have you ever experienced, witnessed, or otherwise been involved in any events that could have brought serious harm or even death to you or someone else? If yes: Specify (in general) (experienced_harmful_events_specify)

module.longName: If 1 is no, protocol is complete
module.preferredDefinition: If 1 is no, protocol is complete

question.questionText: 2. Did this event cause you to have intense feelings of fear, helplessness, or horror? (event_caused_horror)
2.a Did this event cause you to have intense feelings of fear, helplessness, or horror? If yes: Specify (event_caused_horror_specify)

module.longName: If 2 is no, protocol is complete
module.preferredDefinition: If 2 is no, protocol is complete

question.questionText: 3. Have you ever been bothered by unwanted thoughts, or dreams, or images that kept coming back to you, about a traumatic event that you experienced or witnessed? (bothered_by_thoughts_of_event)
4. Have you ever felt as if you were reliving some traumatic event that you experienced or witnessed? (reliving_event)
5. Have you ever been intensely distressed or extremely anxious when you were reminded in some way about a traumatic event that you experienced or witnessed? (anxious_about_event)

module.longName: If 3-5 are all no, protocol is complete
module.preferredDefinition: If 3-5 are all no, protocol is complete

question.questionText: 6. Have you tried in general to avoid thinking or talking about the event? (avoid_thinking_of_event)
7. Have you tried in general to avoid activities, places, or people that remind you of the event? (avoid_activities)
8. Are you unable to recall important parts of the event? (unable_to_remember)
9. Since the event, do you tend to feel detached from other people? (detached_since_event)
10. Since the event, have you been unable to experience a full range of feelings? (full_range_of_feelings)
11. Since the event, have you found yourself unable to see a future for yourself? (unable_to_see_a_future)

module.longName: If less than 3 symptoms, protocol is complete
module.preferredDefinition: If less than 3 symptoms, protocol is complete

question.questionText: 12. Since this event happened, have you had problems with... difficulty falling asleep or staying asleep (apart from depression or mania)? (difficulty_falling_asleep)
13. Since this event happened, have you had problems with... irritability or angry outbursts (apart from depression or mania)? (irritable_since_event)
14. Since this event happened, have you had problems with... difficulty concentrating (apart from depression or mania)? (difficulty_concentrating_since_event)
15. Since this event happened, have you had problems with... being too much on alert? (on_alert_since_event)
16. Since this event happened, have you had problems with... being too easily startled? (easily_startled_since_event)
17. Have you been very upset about having these symptoms? (upset_by_symptoms)
18. Have these symptoms interfered with your ability to work, to be with others, or to function in other areas of life? (symptoms_interfere_with_work)
19. How long did these symptoms (from questions 318) last? Indicate the number of months (symptom_duration)
20. When did the traumatic event occur (if several, ask about the most closely associated with symptoms)? (Year) (when_event_occurred_year)
20. When did the traumatic event occur (if several, ask about the most closely associated with symptoms)? (Month) (when_event_occurred_month)
21. When did you start to experience these symptoms (from questions 318)? (Year) (when_symptoms_started_year)
21. When did you start to experience these symptoms (from questions 318)? (Month) (when_symptoms_started_month)
21.a INTERVIEWER: Compute age of onset (pxt121401_age_of_onset)

protocol.preferredDefinition: The Diagnostic Interview for Genetic Studies (DIGS) Posttraumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) Screener is a 20-question, interviewer-administered questionnaire designed to screen for symptoms of Posttraumatic Stress Disorder. This instrument was adapted from the Genetics of Recurrent Early-Onset Depression (GenRED) research study.

form.longName: PhenX PX121501 - Attentiondeficit Hyperactivity Disorder Symptoms Adul
form.preferredDefinition: The Adult Attention-Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder Self-Report Scale (ASRS-v1.1) Symptom Checklist is an 18-item, two-part questionnaire designed to determine if the participant exhibits Attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder symptoms.

headerInstruction.text: Please answer the questions below, rating yourself on each of the criteria shown. As you answer each question, select the option that best describes how you have felt and conducted yourself over the past 6 months.

question.questionText: 1. How often do you have trouble wrapping up the final details of a project, once the challenging parts have been done? (trouble_wrapping_up_project)
2. How often do you have difficulty getting things in order when you have to do a task that requires organization? (difficulty_getting_orgainized)
3. How often do you have problems remembering appointments or obligations? (difficulty_remembering_appointments)
4. When you have a task that requires a lot of thought, how often do you avoid or delay getting started? (procrastinate_tasks)
5. How often do you fidget or squirm with your hands or feet when you have to sit down for a long time? (fidget_while_sitting)
6. How often do you feel overly active and compelled to do things, like you were driven by a motor? (feel_driven_by_motor)
7. How often do you make careless mistakes when you have to work on a boring or difficult project? (careless_mistakes_tedious_tasks)
8. How often do you have difficulty keeping your attention when you are doing boring or repetitive work? (difficulty_paying_attention_repetitive_tasks)
9. How often do you have difficulty concentrating on what people say to you, even when they are speaking to you directly? (difficulty_concentrating_on_conversations)
10. How often do you misplace or have difficulty finding things at home or at work? (misplace_items_home_work)
11. How often are you distracted by activity or noise around you? (frequency_distracted_by_noise)
12. How often do you leave your seat in meetings or other situations in which you are expected to remain seated? (frequency_leave_seat_at_meetings)
13. How often do you feel restless or fidgety? (frequency_restless)
14. How often do you have difficulty unwinding and relaxing when you have time to yourself? (difficulty_unwinding)
15. How often do you find yourself talking too much when you are in social situations? (frequency_talk_too_much)
16. When you're in a conversation, how often do you find yourself finishing the sentences of the people you are talking to, before they can finish them themselves? (finish_others_sentences)
17. How often do you have difficulty waiting your turn in situations when turn taking is required? (difficulty_waiting_turn)
18. How often do you interrupt others when they are busy? (interrupt_others_when_busy)

instruction.text: Part A. If four or more marks appear in the darkly shaded boxes within Part A, then the patient has symptoms highly consistent with ADHD in adults, and further investigation is warranted. Part B. The frequency scores on Part B provide additional cues and can serve as further probes into the patient's symptoms. Pay particular attention to marks appearing in the darkly shaded boxes. No total score or diagnostic likelihood is utilized for the twelve questions.

question.questionText: Part A. If four or more marks appear in the darkly shaded boxes within Part A, then the patient has symptoms highly consistent with ADHD in adults, and further investigation is warranted. Part B. The frequency scores on Part B provide additional cues and can serve as further probes into the patient's symptoms. Pay particular attention to marks appearing in the darkly shaded boxes. No total score or diagnostic likelihood is utilized for the twelve questions. (scoring_0121501)

protocol.preferredDefinition: The Adult Attention-Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder Self-Report Scale (ASRS-v1.1) Symptom Checklist is an 18-item, two-part questionnaire designed to determine if the participant exhibits Attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder symptoms.

form.longName: PhenX PX121502 - Attentiondeficit Hyperactivity Disorder Symptoms Chil
form.preferredDefinition: The Strengths and Weaknesses of Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder Symptoms and Normal Behavior Scale (SWAN) is an 18-question parent or teacher rating scale to assess for the indication of attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder in children. "Weaknesses" are scored as positive and the "strengths" are scored as negative because the usual ratings (i.e., in the Swanson, Nolan and Pelham (SNAP)) are ratings of "symptom severity". This keeps the average rating-per-item of the SWAN aligned with the average rating-per-item of the SNAP if the negative item ratings of the SWAN are set to 0 before averaging the items.

headerInstruction.text: For each item listed below, how does this child compare to other children of the same age? Please select the best rating based on your observations over the past month. Compared to other children, how does this child do the following:

question.questionText: 1. Give close attention to detail and avoid careless mistakes (close_attention_to_detail)
2. Sustain attention on tasks or play activities (sustain_attention)
3. Listen when spoken to directly (listen_when_spoken_to)
4. Follow through on instructions & finish school work/chores (follow_through_chores)
5. Organize tasks and activities (organize_tasks_activities)
6. Engage in tasks that require sustained mental effort (engage_mental_effort)
7. Keep track of things necessary for activities (keep_track_of_activity_items)
8. Ignore extraneous stimuli (ignore_extraneous_stimuli)
9. Remember daily activities (remember_daily_activities)
10. Sit still (control movement of hands/feet or control squirming) (sit_still)
11. Stay seated (when required by class rules/social conventions) (stay_seated)
12. Modulate motor activity (inhibit inappropriate running/climbing) (modulate_motor_activity)
13. Play quietly (keep noise level reasonable) (play_quietly)
14. Settle down and rest (control constant activity) (settle_down)
15. Modulate verbal activity (control excess talking) (control_excess_talking)
16. Reflect on questions (control blurting out answers) (control_blurting_out)
17. Await turn (stand in line and take turns) (await_turns)
18. Enter into conversation & games (control interrupting/intruding) (control_interrupting)

instruction.text: Each question of the SWAN is scored on a sevenpoint scale, where Far Below Average = 3, Below Average = 2, Somewhat Below Average = 1, Average = 0, Somewhat Above Average = 1, Above Average = 2, and Far Above Average = 3. Subscale scores on the SWAN are calculated by summing the scores on the items in the specific subset (e.g., Inattention) and dividing by the number of items (e.g., 9) to express the summary score as the Average RatingPerItem. If omitted, the item is dropped, not set to 0. If more than half the items are omitted, then the use of the scale score is probably not valid. Look at the table under the Scoring Instructions section here .

question.questionText: Each question of the SWAN is scored on a sevenpoint scale, where Far Below Average = 3, Below Average = 2, Somewhat Below Average = 1, Average = 0, Somewhat Above Average = 1, Above Average = 2, and Far Above Average = 3. Subscale scores on the SWAN are calculated by summing the scores on the items in the specific subset (e.g., Inattention) and dividing by the number of items (e.g., 9) to express the summary score as the Average RatingPerItem. If omitted, the item is dropped, not set to 0. If more than half the items are omitted, then the use of the scale score is probably not valid. Look at the table under the Scoring Instructions section "https://www.phenxtoolkit.org/index.php?pageLink=browse.protocoldetails&id=121502" here . (scoring_0121502)

"Weaknesses" are scored as positive and the "strengths" are scored as negative because the usual ratings (i.e., in the Swanson, Nolan and Pelham (SNAP)) are ratings of "symptom severity". This keeps the average rating-per-item of the SWAN aligned with the average rating-per-item of the SNAP if the negative item ratings of the SWAN are set to 0 before averaging the items.

form.preferredDefinition:
The Triarchic Psychopathy Measure (TriPM) is a 58-item self-report questionnaire designed to measure psychopathy in terms of three distinct phenotypic constructs (Patrick, Fowles, & Krueger, 2009): boldness, defined as the nexus of high dominance, low anxiousness, and venturesomeness; meanness, reflecting tendencies toward callousness, cruelty, predatory aggression, and excitement seeking; and disinhibition, reflecting tendencies toward impulsiveness, irresponsibility, oppositionality, and anger/hostility.
Each construct is measured by a separate subscale. Subscale scores are summed to yield a total psychopathy score.

headerInstruction.text: Triarchic Psychopathy Measure (TriPM): Instructions: This questionnaire contains statements that different people might use to describe themselves. Each statement is followed by four options: True, Somewhat true, Somewhat false, FalseFor each ..TRUNCATED

question.questionText: 1. I'm optimistic more often than not. (optimistic)
2. How other people feel is important to me. (other_peoples_feelings)
3. I often act on immediate needs. (act_on_immediate_needs)
4. I have no strong desire to parachute out of an airplane. (parachute)
5. I've often missed things I promised to attend. (missed_events)
6. I would enjoy being in a highspeed chase. (high_speed_chase)
7. I am wellequipped to deal with stress. (deal_with_stress)
8. I don't mind if someone I dislike gets hurt. (someone_i_dislike_gets_hurt)
9. My impulsive decisions have caused problems with loved ones. (impulsive_decisions)
10. I get scared easily. (easily_scared)
11. I sympathize with others' problems. (sympathize_with_others)
12. I have missed work without bothering to call in. (missed_work_without_calling)
13. I'm a born leader. (born_leader)
14. I enjoy a good physical fight. (enjoy_physical_fight)
15. I jump into things without thinking. (jump_without_thinking)
16. I have a hard time making things turn out the way I want. (things_turn_out_my_way)
17. I return insults. (return_insults)
18. I've gotten in trouble because I missed too much school. (missed_too_much_school)
19. I have a knack for influencing people. (influence_people)
20. It doesn't bother me to see someone else in pain. (other_peoples_pain)
21. I have good control over myself. (good_self_control)
22. I function well in new situations, even when unprepared. (new_situations)
23. I enjoy pushing people around sometimes. (enjoy_pushing_others_around)
24. I have taken money from someone's purse or wallet without asking. (take_money_from_wallet)
25. I don't think of myself as talented. (not_talented)
26. I taunt people just to stir things up. (taunt_others)
27. People often abuse my trust. (abuse_trust)
28. I'm afraid of far fewer things than most people. (less_fear_than_others)
29. I don't see any point in worrying if what I do hurts someone else. (not_worried_about_hurting_others)
30. I keep appointments I make. (keep_appointments)
31. I often get bored quickly and lose interest. (bore_quickly)
32. I can get over things that would traumatize others. (not_traumatized_like_others)
33. I am sensitive to the feelings of others. (sensitive_to_others_feelings)
34. I have conned people to get money from them. (conned_people_for_money)
35. It worries me to go into an unfamiliar situation without knowing all the details. (worried_about_unfamiliar_situations)
36. I don't have much sympathy for people. (no_sympathy_for_others)
37. I get in trouble for not considering the consequences of my actions. (trouble_not_consider_consequences)
38. I can convince people to do what I want. (convince_others)
39. For me, honesty really is the best policy. (honesty_best_policy)
40. I've injured people to see them in pain. (injured_to_see_pain)
41. I don't like to take the lead in groups. (dont_like_lead_groups)
42. I sometimes insult people on purpose to get a reaction from them. (insult_to_get_reaction)
43. I have taken items from a store without paying for them. (stolen_from_store)
44. It's easy to embarrass me. (easily_embarrassed)
45. Things are more fun if a little danger is involved. (enjoy_danger)
46. I have a hard time waiting patiently for things I want. (hard_to_wait)
47. I stay away from physical danger as much as I can. (avoid_physical_danger)
48. I don't care much if what I do hurts others. (dont_mind_hurting_others)
49. I have lost a friend because of irresponsible things I've done. (actions_lost_friends)
50. I don't stack up well against most others. (stack_up_to_others)
51. Others have told me they are concerned about my lack of selfcontrol. (others_concerned_lack_self_control)
52. It's easy for me to relate to other people's emotions. (relate_to_peoples_emotions)
53. I have robbed someone. (robbed_someone)
54. I never worry about making a fool of myself with others. (not_worried_about_looking_foolish)
55. It doesn't bother me when people around me are hurting. (not_bothered_by_people_hurting)
56. I have had problems at work because I was irresponsible. (problems_at_work_because_irresponsible)
57. I'm not very good at influencing people. (not_good_at_influencing_others)
58. I have stolen something out of a vehicle. (stolen_from_vehicle)

instruction.text: Code responses for all other items as follows: True = 3 Somewhat true = 2 Somewhat false = 1 False = 0. Step 2: Computing Scale Scores and Total Scores Boldness subscale (19 items)Sum coded responses for the following items: 1, 4, 7, 10, 13, 16, 19, 22, 25, 28, 32, 35, 38, 41, 44, 47, 50, 54, 57 Meanness subscale (19 items)Sum coded responses for the following items: 2, 6, 8, 11, 14, 17, 20, 23, 26, 29, 33, 36, 39, 40, 42, 45, 48, 52, 55 Disinhibition subscale (20 items)Sum coded responses for the following items: 3, 5, 9, 12, 15, 18, 21, 24, 27, 30, 31, 34, 37, 43, 46, 49, 51, 53, 56, 58 Total Psychopathy scoreSum scores across the three subscales.

(scoring_0121601)

question.questionText: Step 1: Coding Responses For items followed by [F]i.e., items 2, 4, 10, 11, 16, 21, 25, 30, 33, 35, 39, 41, 44, 47, 50, 52, 57code responses as follows: True = 0 Somewhat true = 1 Somewhat false = 2 False = 3. Scoring: Add up scores from the individual questions. A score of 108 represents extreme disability. A score of 0 represents little / no disability. For each question: 0 pt=First choice (EX: normal, absent, normal erect, none) 1 pt=Second choice 2 pt=Third choice 3 pt=Fourth choice 4 pt=Fifth choice (scoring_130101)

protocol.preferredDefinition: The Motor Exam portion of the United Parkinson's Disease Rating Scale is a 27 item examiner-administered test that measures the severity of symptoms in resting tremor, resistance to movement and abnormal gait and posture.

form.preferredDefinition: The Charcot-Marie-Tooth Neuropathy Score is a nine-item clinical examination that measures sensory symptoms, motor symptoms, arm and leg strength and nerve conduction velocities.
