form.longName: PhenX PX130301 - History Of Stroke Ischemic Infarction And Hemorrhage
form.preferredDefinition: The Stroke Symptoms Form from the Jackson Heart Study is an interviewer-administered questionnaire that captures the history of stroke(s) and associated symptoms such as slurred speech, double vision, loss of vision and paralysis.

module.longName: History Of Stroke Ischemic Infarction And Hemorrhage
module.preferredDefinition: History Of Stroke Ischemic Infarction And Hemorrhage

question.questionText: 1. Have you ever been told by a physician that you had a stroke? (physician_diagnosed_stroke)
2. What date did the first stroke occur? (date_stroke_occurred)
3. Have you ever had any sudden loss or changes in speech lasting 24 hours or longer? (sudden_loss_of_speech)
4. Did the episode come on suddenly? (episode_occur_suddenly)
5. Do any of the following describe your change in speech? (px0130301_q5)
5a. Slurred speech like you were drunk? (slurred_speech)
5b. Could talk but the wrong words came out? (wrong_words)
5c. Knew what you wanted to say, but the words would not come out? (words_would_not_come_out)
5d. Could not think of the right words? (could_not_find_right_words)
5e. "IF MORE THAN ONE OF ITEMS 5a5d INDICATED, ASK WHICH OF THESE MOST CLOSELY DESCRIBES THE PROBLEM?" (most_representative_symptom)
6. While you were having your episode of change in speech, did any of the following occur? [INCLUDE ALL THAT APPLY] (px130301_q6)
6a. Numbness or tingling? (numbness_or_tingling)
6b. Did you have difficulty on: (side_with_numbness_tingling)
6c. Paralysis or weakness? (paralysis_or_weakness)
6d. Did you have difficulty on: (side_with_paralysis_weakness)
6e. Lightheadedness, dizziness, or loss of balance? (lightheadedness_dizziness_loss_of_balance)
6f. Blackouts or fainting? (blackouts_or_fainting)
6g. Seizures or convulsions? (seizures_or_convulsions)
6h. Headache? (headache)
6i. Visual disturbances? (visual_disturbances)
6j. Did you have: (vision_disturbances_description)
7. Have you ever had any sudden loss of vision, or blurring, lasting 24 hours or longer? (sudden_vision_loss_or_blurring)
8. Did the episode come on suddenly? (episode_came_on_suddenly)
9. During the episode, which of the following parts of your vision were affected? (parts_of_vision_affected)
9a. Did you have: (trouble_seeing_left_right_ahead)
10. While you were having your loss of vision, did any of the following occur? (px130301_q10)
10a. Speech disturbance? (speech_disturbance_with_vision_loss)
10b. Numbness or tingling? (numbness_tingling_with_vision_loss)
10c. Did you have difficulty on: (complications_side_affected_vision_loss)
10d. While you were having your loss of vision, did any of the following occur? Paralysis or weakness? (paralysis_weakness_with_vision_loss)
10e. Did you have difficulty on: (paralysis_weakness_vision_loss_side)
10f. Lightheadedness, dizziness, or loss of balance? (lightheadedness_dizziness_balance_vision_loss)
10g. Blackouts or fainting? (blackouts_fainting_with_vision_loss)
10h. Seizures or convulsions? (seizures_convulsions_with_vision_loss)
10i. Headache? (headache_with_vision_loss)
10j. Flashing lights? (flashing_lights_with_vision_loss)
11. Have you ever had a sudden spell of double vision, which lasted 24 hours or longer? (sudden_spell_double_vision)
11a. If you closed one eye, did the double vision go away? (double_vision_one_eye)
12. Did the episode come on suddenly? (double_vision_occurred_suddenly)
13. While you were having your double vision did any of the following occur? (px130301_q13)
13a. Speech disturbance? (speech_disturbance_with_double_vision)
13b. Numbness or tingling? (numbness_tingling_with_double_vision)
13c. Did you have difficulty on: (affected_side_numbness_double_vision)
13d. While you were having your double vision did any of the following occur? Paralysis or weakness? (paralysis_weakness_with_double_vision)
13e. Did you have difficulty on: (affected_side_paralysis_double_vision)
13f. Lightheadedness, dizziness, or loss of balance? (lightheadedness_with_double_vision)
13g. Blackouts or fainting? (blackouts_fainting_with_double_vision)
13h. Seizures or convulsions? (seizures_convulsions_with_double_vision)
13i. Headache? (headache_with_double_vision)
14. Have you ever had sudden numbness, tingling, or loss of feeling on one side of your body, including your face, arm, or leg which lasted 24 hours or longer? (sudden_numbness_tingling)
15. Did the feeling of numbness or tingling occur only when you kept your arms or legs in a certain position? (numbness_tingling_in_certain_position)
16. Did the episode come on suddenly? (numbness_tingling_occur_suddenly)
17. During the episode of sudden numbness or tingling, which part or parts of your body were affected? (px130301_q17)
17a. Left arm or hand? (numbness_left_arm_or_hand)
17b. Left leg or foot? (numbness_left_leg_or_foot)
17c. Left side of face? (numbness_left_side_of_face)
17d. Right arm or hand? (numbness_right_arm_or_hand)
17e. Right leg or foot? (numbness_right_leg_or_foot)
17f. Right side of face? (numbness_right_side_of_face)
17g. Other? (numbness_other)
18. During this episode, did the abnormal sensation start in one part of your body and spread to another, or did it stay in the same place? (sensation_spread)
19. While you were having your episode of numbness, tingling or loss of sensation, did any of the following occur? (px130301_q19)
19a. Speech disturbance? (speech_disturbance_with_numbness)
19b. Paralysis or weakness? (paralysis_or_weakness_with_numbness)
19c. Did you have difficulty on: (affected_side_complications_with_numbness)
19d. Lightheadedness, dizziness, or loss of balance? (lightheadedness_with_numbness)
19e. Blackouts or fainting? (blackouts_or_fainting_with_numbness)
19f. Seizures or convulsions? (seizures_or_convulsions_with_numbness)
19g. Headache? (headache_with_numbness)
19h. Pain in the numb or tingling arm, leg or face? (pain_with_numbness)
19i. Visual disturbances? (visual_disturbances_with_numbness)
19j. Did you have: (visual_disturbances_description_with_numbness)
20. Have you ever had any sudden episode of paralysis or weakness on one side of your body, including your face, arm, or leg which lasted at least 24 hours? (sudden_paralysis_or_weakness)
21. Did the episode come on suddenly? (paralysis_or_weakness_occurred_suddenly)
22. During this episode, which part or parts of your body were affected? (px130301_q22)
22a. Left arm or hand? (paralysis_weakness_left_arm_hand)
22b. Left leg or foot? (paralysis_weakness_left_leg_foot)
22c. Left side of face? (paralysis_weakness_left_side_face)
22d. Right arm or hand? (paralysis_weakness_right_arm_hand)
22e. Right leg or foot? (paralysis_weakness_right_leg_foot)
22f. Right side of face? (paralysis_weakness_right_side_face)
22g. Other? (paralysis_weakness_other)
23. During this episode, did the paralysis or weakness start in one part of your body and spread to another, or did it stay in the same place? (paralysis_weakness_spread)
24. While you were having your episode of paralysis or weakness, did any of the following occur? (px130301_q24)
24a. Speech disturbances? (speech_disturbances_with_paralysis_weakness)
24b. Numbness or tingling? (numbness_with_paralysis_weakness)
24c. Did you have difficulty on: (side_affected_with_paralysis_weakness)
24d. Lightheadedness, dizziness, or loss of balance? (lightheadedness_with_paralysis_weakness)
24e. Blackouts or fainting? (blackouts_with_paralysis_weakness)
24f. Seizures or convulsions? (seizures_with_paralysis_weakness)
24g. Headache? (headache_with_paralysis_weakness)
24h. Pain in the weak arm, leg or face? (pain_with_paralysis_weakness)
24i. Visual disturbances? (visual_disturbances_with_paralysis_weakness)
24j. Did you have: (visual_disturbances_description_paralysis_weakness)
25. Have you had any sudden spells of dizziness, loss of balance, or sensation of spinning which lasted 24 hours or longer? (dizziness_loss_of_balance)
26. Did the dizziness, loss of balance or spinning sensation occur only when changing the position of your head or body? (dizziness_change_position_only)
27. While you were having your episode of dizziness, loss of balance or spinning sensation, did any of the following occur? (px130301_q27)
27a. Speech disturbances? (speech_disturbances_with_dizziness)
27b. Paralysis or weakness? (paralysis_weakness_with_dizziness)
27c. Did you have difficulty on: (affected_side_paralysis_with_dizziness)
27d. Numbness or tingling? (numbness_with_dizziness)
27e. Did you have difficulty on: (affected_side_numbness_with_dizziness)
27f. Blackouts or fainting? (blackouts_with_dizziness)
27g. Seizures or convulsions? (seizures_with_dizziness)
27h. Headache? (headache_with_dizziness)
27i. Visual disturbances? (visual_disturbances_with_dizziness)
27j. Did you have: (visual_disturbances_description_with_dizziness)
28. Did the episode of dizziness, loss of balance, or spinning sensation come on suddenly? (dizziness_occurred_suddenly)

protocol.longName: History of Stroke - Ischemic Infarction and Hemorrhage
protocol.preferredDefinition: The Stroke Symptoms Form from the Jackson Heart Study is an interviewer-administered questionnaire that captures the history of stroke(s) and associated symptoms such as slurred speech, double vision, loss of vision and paralysis.

form.preferredDefinition: The following protocol is a nine-item interviewer-administered questionnaire to screen for the presence of epilepsy.

question.questionText: Did anyone ever tell you that you had a seizure or convulsion caused by a high fever when you were a child? (seizure_or_convulsion)
[Other than the seizure[s] you had because of a high fever] Have you ever had, or has anyone ever told you that you had, a seizure disorder or epilepsy? (have_seizure_disorder_or_epilepsy)
Have you ever had, or has anyone ever told you that you had, a seizure disorder or epilepsy? (have_seizure_disorder2_b49)

[Other than the seizure[s] you had because of a high fever] Have you ever had, or has anyone ever told you that you had, any of the following... A seizure, convulsion, fit or spell under any circumstances? (other_seizure)
Have you ever had, or has anyone ever told you that you had, any of the following... A seizure, convulsion, fit or spell under any circumstances? (other_seizure2_963)

[Other than the seizure[s] you had because of a high fever] Have you ever had, or has anyone ever told you that you had, any of the following... Uncontrolled movements of part or all of your body such as twitching, jerking, shaking or going limp? (uncontrolled_movements)

Have you ever had, or has anyone ever told you that you had, any of the following... Uncontrolled movements of part or all of your body such as twitching, jerking, shaking or going limp? (uncontrolled_movement2_029)

[Other than the seizure[s] you had because of a high fever] Have you ever had, or has anyone ever told you that you had, any of the following... An unexplained change in your mental state or level of awareness or an episode of spacing out that you could not control? (unexplained_change_in_mental)

Have you ever had, or has anyone ever told you that you had, any of the following... An unexplained change in your mental state or level of awareness or an episode of spacing out that you could not control? (unexplained_change_in2_dc8)

[Other than the seizure[s] you had because of a high fever] Have you ever had, or has anyone ever told you that you had, any of the following... Did anyone ever tell you that when you were a small child, you would daydream or stare into space more than other children? (daydream_or_stare_into_space)

Have you ever had, or has anyone ever told you that you had, any of the following... Did anyone ever tell you that when you were a small child, you would daydream or stare into space more than other children? (daydream_or_stare_int2_0f9)

[Other than the seizure[s] you had because of a high fever] Have you ever had, or has anyone ever told you that you had, any of the following... Have you ever noticed any unusual body movements or feelings when exposed to strobe lights, video games, flickering lights, or sun glare? (strobe_lights_response)

Have you ever had, or has anyone ever told you that you had, any of the following... Have you ever noticed any unusual body movements or feelings when exposed to strobe lights, video games, flickering lights, or sun glare? (strobe_lights_respons2_27e)

[Other than the seizure[s] you had because of a high fever] Have you ever had, or has anyone ever told you that you had, any of the following... Shortly after waking up, either in the morning or after a nap, have you ever noticed uncontrollable jerking or clumsiness, such as dropping things or things suddenly "flying" from your hands? (uncontrollable_jerking_or_clumsiness)

Have you ever had, or has anyone ever told you that you had, any of the following... Shortly after waking up, either in the morning or after a nap, have you ever noticed uncontrollable jerking or clumsiness, such as dropping things or things suddenly "flying" from your hands? (uncontrollable_jerkin2_f42)

[Other than the seizure[s] you had because of a high fever] Have you ever had, or has anyone ever told you that you had, any of the following... Have you ever had any other type of repeated unusual spells? (other_repeated_unusual_spells)
Have you ever had, or has anyone ever told you that you had, any of the following... Have you ever had any other type of repeated unusual spells? (other_repeated_unusua2_4a2)

protocol.preferredDefinition: The following protocol is a nine-item interviewer-administered questionnaire to screen for the presence of epilepsy.

form.preferredDefinition: The Self-Administered Questionnaire for Migraine is a 20-item questionnaire that assesses the frequency of severe headaches, the level of pain, whether the person is taking medications, and associated complications such as nausea.

question.questionText: 1. Over the past year, have you suffered from severe headaches? (severe_headaches_last_year)
2. Age: (current_age)
3. Sex (gender)
4. When you have a severe headache, do you experience any of the following? (check all that apply) (headache_complications_numbness_enum)

validValue.meaningText: Pain-free intervals of days or weeks between severe headache attacks
validValue.description: Pain-free intervals of days or weeks between severe headache attacks

validValue.meaningText: Seeing shimmering lights, circles, other shapes, or colors before the eyes, before the headache starts
validValue.description: Seeing shimmering lights, circles, other shapes, or colors before the eyes, before the headache starts

validValue.meaningText: Numbness of lips, tongue, fingers, or legs before the headache starts
validValue.description: Numbness of lips, tongue, fingers, or legs before the headache starts

question.questionText: 4a. About how often do your severe headaches occur? (Write In Number Of Headache Days You Have Per Week, Month or Year please specify which in answer) (severe_headaches_average_frequency)
5. Which statement best describes the pain of your severe headaches? (Check ONE) (severe_headache_pain_type)
6. Which best describes how you are usually affected by severe headaches? (Check ONE) (how_affected_by_headaches)

validValue.meaningText: Working ability or activity impaired to some degree
validValue.description: Working ability or activity impaired to some degree

validValue.meaningText: Working ability or activity severely impaired
validValue.description: Working ability or activity severely impaired

question.questionText: 7. Each time you have a severe headache, how long are you unable to work or undertake normal activities? (Check ONE) (how_long_unable_to_work)
8. On how many days in the last 3 months did you have a headache (if headache lasted more than 1 day, count each day)? (headache_frequency_last_three_months)
9a. Because of your headaches on how many days in the last 3 months... ? did you miss work or school (number_days_miss_school)

9b. Because of your headaches on how many days in the last 3 months... ? was your productivity at work/school reduced by half or more (not including days missed in qu. 9a above) (number_days_reduced_productivity)
9c. Because of your headaches on how many days in the last 3 months... ? did you not do household work (number_days_no_house_work)

9d. Because of your headaches on how many days in the last 3 months... ? was your productivity in household work reduced by half or more (not including days counted in qu. 9c above) (number_days_housework_reduced_half)
9e. Because of your headaches on how many days in the last 3 months... ? did you miss family, social, or leisure activities (number_days_miss_activities)
10. At what age did you BEGIN having severe headaches? (age_headaches_began)
11. Have you ever gone to the hospital emergency room or to an urgent care clinic because of your severe headaches? (ever_goneto_hospital_for_headaches)
12. Which best describes the way you usually treat severe headaches? (Check ONE) (usual_headache_treatment)

validValue.meaningText: Take both prescription and non-prescription medications
validValue.description: Take both prescription and non-prescription medications

question.questionText: 13. Have you ever taken prescription medication for headache on a DAILY basis, whether or not you have a headache, to help prevent a severe headache from happening in the first place? (headache_prescription_medication_daily_basis)
14. Are you currently taking any other medication on a DAILY basis? (Check all that apply) (any_other_daily_medication_prescription_depression_enum)

validValue.meaningText: Water pill or prescription diuretic for high blood pressure
validValue.description: Water pill or prescription diuretic for high blood pressure

validValue.meaningText: Prescription medicine (other than water pill) for high blood pressure
validValue.description: Prescription medicine (other than water pill) for high blood pressure

validValue.meaningText: Prescription medicine for seizures, epilepsy, or fits
validValue.description: Prescription medicine for seizures, epilepsy, or fits

validValue.meaningText: Prescription medicine for depression or anxiety
validValue.description: Prescription medicine for depression or anxiety

question.questionText: 15. When did you last take prescription medication for headache on a DAILY basis to help prevent a severe headache from happening in the first place? (Check ONE) (last_took_daily_headache_medication)

validValue.meaningText: Last took within the past 3 months
validValue.description: Last took within the past 3 months

validValue.meaningText: Last took more than 12 months ago
validValue.description: Last took more than 12 months ago

question.questionText: 16. Do you consider your severe headaches to be migraines? (consider_headaches_tobe_migraines)
17. Have you ever been diagnosed by a physician or other health professional as suffering from... (Check all that apply) (diagnosed_with_headache_type_migraine_enum)
18. If diagnosed with migraines, at what age were you FIRST DIAGNOSED with migraines? (age_diagnosed_with_migraines)
19a. Height in feet? (height_feet)
19b. Height in inches? (height_inches)
20. Current weight in pounds? (weight)

Scoring Instructions In Lipton et al. (2001), respondents were classified as suffering from migraine if they fulfill the criteria for migraine with aura and migraine without aura established in 1998 by the International Headache Society (IHS) (Headache Classification Committee of the International Headache Society, 1998). This included one or more severe headache in the last year with "unilateral or pulsatile pain, and either nausea, vomiting, or phonophobia with photophobia or visual or sensory aura before the headache" (Lipton et al., 2001). These criteria were updated by the International Headache Society in 2004 (Headache Classification Subcommittee of the International Headache Society, 2004). (scoring_130501)

protocol.preferredDefinition: The Self-Administered Questionnaire for Migraine is a 20-item questionnaire that assesses the frequency of severe headaches, the level of pain, whether the person is taking medications, and associated complications such as nausea.

form.longName: PhenX PX130601 - History Of Head Trauma
form.preferredDefinition: The Ohio State University Traumatic Brain Injury Identification Method Short Form (OSU TBI-ID) is an interviewer-administered questionnaire that captures the lifetime history of traumatic brain injury. The OSU TBI-ID gives data for calculating summary indices that reflect the likelihood that consequences have resulted from lifetime exposure to traumatic brain injury.

headerInstruction.text: We would like to ask you about injuries to your head or neck that you may have had at anytime in your life. LOC=loss of consciousness (knocked out) TBI=traumatic brain injury

question.questionText: 1. Have you ever been hospitalized or treated in an emergency room following an injury to your head or neck? Think about any childhood injuries you remember or were told about. (hospitalized_head_injury)
Cause of injury reported in question 1 (hospitalized_head_injury_cause)
1a. Were you knocked out or did you lose consciousness? If yes, how long? (head_or_neck_injury_loc)
1b. If no, were you dazed or did you have a gap in your memory from the injury? (head_injury_memory_gap)
1c. How old were you? (head_or_neck_injury_age)
2. Have you ever injured your head or neck in a car accident or from some other moving vehicle accident (e.g. motorcycle, ATV)? (moving_vehicle_head_injury)
Cause of injury reported in question 2 (moving_vehicle_head_injury_cause)
2a. Were you knocked out or did you lose consciousness (LOC)? If yes, how long? (moving_vehicle_head_injury_loc)
2b. If no, were you dazed or did you have a gap in your memory from the injury? (vehicular_head_injury_memory_gap)
2c. How old were you? (moving_vehicle_head_injury_age)

3. Have you ever injured your head or neck in a fall or from being hit by something (e.g. falling from a bike, horse, or rollerblades, falling on ice, being hit by a rock)? Have you ever injured your head or neck playing sports or on the playground? (head_injury_fall_hit_sports)
Cause of injury reported in question 3 (fall_head_injury_cause)
3a. Were you knocked out or did you lose consciousness (LOC)? If yes, how long? (fall_head_injury_loc)
3b. If no, were you dazed or did you have a gap in your memory from the injury? (fall_head_injury_memory_gap)
3c. How old were you? (fall_head_injury_age)
4. Have you ever injured your head or neck in a fight, from being hit by someone, or from being shaken violently? Have you ever been shot in the head? (head_injury_fight)
Cause of injury reported in question 4 (fight_head_injury_cause)
4a. Were you knocked out or did you lose consciousness (LOC)? If yes, how long? (fight_head_injury_loc)
4b. If no, were you dazed or did you have a gap in your memory from the injury? (fight_head_injury_memory_gap)
4c. How old were you? (fight_head_injury_age)
5. Have you ever been nearby when an explosion or a blast occurred? If you served in the military, think about any combat or trainingrelated incidents. (explosion_head_injury)
Cause of injury reported in question 5 (explosion_head_injury_cause)
5a. Were you knocked out or did you lose consciousness (LOC)? If yes, how long? (explosion_head_injury_loc)
5b. If no, were you dazed or did you have a gap in your memory from the injury? (explosion_head_injury_memory_gap)
5c. How old were you? (explosion_head_injury_age)
6. If more injuries with LOC: How many more? (number_other_injuries_with_loc)
If more injuries with LOC: Longest knocked out (other_injuries_with_loc_longest)
If more injuries with LOC: How many > 30 mins.? (number_other_injuries_with_loc_30min)
If more injuries with LOC: Youngest age? (number_other_injuries_with_loc_age)
7a. Have you ever lost consciousness from a drug overdose? If so, record the number of times. (loc_from_drug_overdose)
7b. Have you ever lost consciousness from being choked? If so, record the number of times. (loc_from_being_choked)

SCORING _____ # TBILOC (number of TBI's with loss of consciousness from #15a) ____ # TBILOC ? 30 (number of TBI's with loss of consciousness ? 30 minutes from #15a) ____ age at first TBILOC (youngest age from #15c) ____ TBILOC before age 15 (if youngest age from #15c < 15 then =1, if ? 15 then = 0) ____ Worst Injury (15): If responses to #15 are "no", classify as 1 "improbable TBI". If in response to #15a and #15b reports never having LOC, being dazed or having memory lapses, classify as 1 "improbable TBI". If in response to #15b reports being dazed or having a memory lapse, classify as 2 "possible TBI". If in response to #15a loss of consciousness (LOC) does not exceed 30 minutes for any injury, classify as 3 "mild TBI". If in response to #15a LOC for any one injury is between 30 minutes and 24 hours, classify as 4 "moderate TBI". If in response to #15a LOC for any one injury exceeds 24 hours, classify as 5 "severe TBI".____ # anoxic injuries (sum of incidents reported in #7ab) This protocol was adapted with permission from the Ohio State University TBI Identification Method reserved 2007, The Ohio Valley Center for Brain Injury Prevention and Rehabilitation (scoring_130601)

protocol.preferredDefinition: The Ohio State University Traumatic Brain Injury Identification Method Short Form (OSU TBI-ID) is an interviewer-administered questionnaire that captures the lifetime history of traumatic brain injury. The OSU TBI-ID gives data for calculating summary indices that reflect the likelihood that consequences have resulted from lifetime exposure to traumatic brain injury.

form.longName: PhenX PX130701 - Global Mental Status Screener Adult
form.preferredDefinition: The Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MoCA) is a screening instrument for mild cognitive impairment and more severe cognitive deficits. It is an interviewer-administered questionnaire in which the respondent performs certain tasks, such as drawing and counting, to assess various cognitive domains, such as attention, memory, orientation, language, conceptual thinking and planning.

headerInstruction.text: Please consult www.mocatest.org for permission and requirements to use the MoCA test.

question.questionText: IMAGE (moca_image)

Please draw a line, going from a number to a letter in ascending order. Begin here [point to (1)] and draw a line from 1 then to A then to 2 and so on. End here [point to (E)].",0 (alternate_trail_making)
Copy this drawing as accurately as you can, in the space below (visuoconstructional_skills_cube)
Draw a clock. Put in all the numbers and set the time to 10 after 11. (visuoconstructional_skills_clock)
Tell me the name this animal (naming_camel)
Tell me the name this animal (naming_lion)
Tell me the name this animal (naming_rhinoceros)

This is a memory test. I am going to read a list of words that you will have to remember now and later on. Listen carefully. When I am through, tell me as many words as you can remember. It doesn't matter in what order you say them. Face (immediate_recall_face_trial1)

This is a memory test. I am going to read a list of words that you will have to remember now and later on. Listen carefully. When I am through, tell me as many words as you can remember. It doesn't matter in what order you say them. Velvet (immediate_recall_velvet_trial1)

This is a memory test. I am going to read a list of words that you will have to remember now and later on. Listen carefully. When I am through, tell me as many words as you can remember. It doesn't matter in what order you say them. Church (immediate_recall_church_trial1)

This is a memory test. I am going to read a list of words that you will have to remember now and later on. Listen carefully. When I am through, tell me as many words as you can remember. It doesn't matter in what order you say them. Daisy (immediate_recall_daisy_trial1)

This is a memory test. I am going to read a list of words that you will have to remember now and later on. Listen carefully. When I am through, tell me as many words as you can remember. It doesn't matter in what order you say them. Red (immediate_recall_red_trial1)
I am going to read the same list for a second time. Try to remember and tell me as many words as you can, including words you said the first time. Face (immediate_recall_face_trial2)
I am going to read the same list for a second time. Try to remember and tell me as many words as you can, including words you said the first time. Velvet (immediate_recall_velvet_trial2)
I am going to read the same list for a second time. Try to remember and tell me as many words as you can, including words you said the first time. Church (immediate_recall_church_trial2)
I am going to read the same list for a second time. Try to remember and tell me as many words as you can, including words you said the first time. Daisy (immediate_recall_daisy_trial2)
I am going to read the same list for a second time. Try to remember and tell me as many words as you can, including words you said the first time. Red (immediate_recall_red_trial2)
I am going to say some numbers and when I am through, repeat them to me exactly as I said them. 2,1,8,5,4 (digit_span_forward)
Now I am going to say some more numbers, but when I am through you must repeat them to me the in the backwards order. 7,4,2 (digit_span_backward)

I am going to read a sequence of letters. Every time I say the letter A, tap your hand once. If I say a different letter, do not tap your hand. F,B,A,C,M,N,A,A,J,K,L,B,A,F,A,K,D,E,A,A,A,J,A,M,O,F,A,A,B (vigilance)
Now, I will ask you to count by subtracting seven from 100, and then, keep subtracting seven from your answer until I tell you to stop. (serial_sevens)
I am going to read you, a sentence. Repeat it after me, exactly as I say it [pause]: I only know that John is the one to help today. (sentence_repetition_1)
Now I am going to read you another sentence. Repeat it after me, exactly as I say it [pause]: The cat always hid under the couch when dogs were in the room. (sentence_repetition_2)

Tell me as many words as you can think of that begin with a certain letter of the alphabet that I will tell you in a moment. You can sav any kind of word you want, except for proper nouns (like Bob or Boston), numbers, or words that begin with the same sound but have a different suffix, for example, love, lover, loving. I will tell you to stop after one minute. Are you ready? [Pause] Now, tell me as many words as you can think of that begin with the letter F. [time for 60 sec]. Stop. (verbal_fluency)
Now, tell me how a train and a bicycle are alike. (abstraction_1)
Now tell me how a ruler and a watch are alike. (abstraction_2)

"I read some words to you earlier, which I asked you to remember. Tell me as many of those words as you can remember." Make a check mark (?) for each of the words correctly recalled spontaneously without any cues, in the allocated space. Scoring: Allocate 1 point for each word recalled freely without any cues. (delayed_recall)
Tell me the date today (orientation_1)
If subject does not give a complete date, then: "Tell me the [year, month, exact data, and day of the week[" (orientation_2)
Tell me the name of this place, and which city it is in. (orientation_3)

protocol.preferredDefinition: The Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MoCA) is a screening instrument for mild cognitive impairment and more severe cognitive deficits. It is an interviewer-administered questionnaire in which the respondent performs certain tasks, such as drawing and counting, to assess various cognitive domains, such as attention, memory, orientation, language, conceptual thinking and planning.

form.longName: PhenX PX131201 - Gross Motor Function 24 Years Old
form.preferredDefinition: The Gross Motor Function Classification System (GMFCS) Family Report Questionnaire is a five item parent-report instrument that classifies children with Cerebral Palsy based on current motor ability including the need for assistive technology.

question.questionText: My child... (gross_motor_function)

validValue.meaningText: Has difficulty controlling head and trunk posture in most positions and uses specially adapted seating to sit comfortably and has to be lifted by another person to move about
validValue.description: Has difficulty controlling head and trunk posture in most positions and uses specially adapted seating to sit comfortably and has to be lifted by another person to move about

validValue.meaningText: Can sit on own when placed on the floor and can move within a room and uses hands for support to maintain sitting balance and usually uses adaptive equipment for sitting and standing and moves by rolling, creeping on stomach or crawling
validValue.description: Can sit on own when placed on the floor and can move within a room and uses hands for support to maintain sitting balance and usually uses adaptive equipment for sitting and standing and moves by rolling, creeping on stomach or crawling

validValue.meaningText: Can sit on own and walk short distances with a walking aid (such as a walker, rollator, crutches, canes, etc.) and may need help from an adult for steering and turning when walking with an aid and usually sits on floor in a "W-sitting" position and may need help from an adult to get into sitting and may pull to stand and cruise short distances and prefers to move by creeping and crawling
validValue.description: Can sit on own and walk short distances with a walking aid (such as a walker, rollator, crutches, canes, etc.) and may need help from an adult for steering and turning when walking with an aid and usually sits on floor in a "W-sitting" position and may need help from an adult to get into sitting and may pull to stand and cruise short distances and prefers to move by creeping and crawling

validValue.meaningText: Can sit on own and usually moves by walking with a walking aid and may have difficulty with sitting balance when using both hands to play and can get in and out of sitting positions on own and can pull to stand and cruise holding onto furniture and can crawl but prefers to move by walking
validValue.description: Can sit on own and usually moves by walking with a walking aid and may have difficulty with sitting balance when using both hands to play and can get in and out of sitting positions on own and can pull to stand and cruise holding onto furniture and can crawl but prefers to move by walking

protocol.preferredDefinition: The Gross Motor Function Classification System (GMFCS) Family Report Questionnaire is a five item parent-report instrument that classifies children with Cerebral Palsy based on current motor ability including the need for assistive technology.

form.longName: PhenX PX131202 - Gross Motor Function 46 Years Old
form.preferredDefinition: The Gross Motor Function Classification System (GMFCS) Family Report Questionnaire is a five item parent-report instrument that classifies children with cerebral palsy based on current motor ability including the need for assistive technology.

question.questionText: My child... (pxt131202_gross_motor_function)

validValue.meaningText: Has difficulty sitting on their own and controlling their head and body posture in most positions and has difficulty achieving any voluntary control of movement and needs a specially-adapted supportive chair to sit comfortably and has to be lifted or hoisted by another person to move
validValue.description: Has difficulty sitting on their own and controlling their head and body posture in most positions and has difficulty achieving any voluntary control of movement and needs a specially-adapted supportive chair to sit comfortably and has to be lifted or hoisted by another person to move

validValue.meaningText: Can sit on their own but does not stand or walk without significant support and adult supervision and may need extra body / trunk support to improve arm and hand function and usually needs adult assistance to get in and out of a chair and may achieve self-mobility using a powered wheelchair or is transported in the community
validValue.description: Can sit on their own but does not stand or walk without significant support and adult supervision and may need extra body / trunk support to improve arm and hand function and usually needs adult assistance to get in and out of a chair and may achieve self-mobility using a powered wheelchair or is transported in the community

validValue.meaningText: Can walk on their own using a walking aid (such as a walker, rollator, crutches, canes, etc.) and can usually get in and out of a chair without adult assistance and may use a wheelchair when travelling long distances or outside and finds it difficult to climb stairs or walk on an uneven surface without considerable help
validValue.description: Can walk on their own using a walking aid (such as a walker, rollator, crutches, canes, etc.) and can usually get in and out of a chair without adult assistance and may use a wheelchair when travelling long distances or outside and finds it difficult to climb stairs or walk on an uneven surface without considerable help

validValue.meaningText: Can walk on their own without using a walking aid, but has difficulty walking long distances or on uneven surfaces and can sit in a normal adult chair and use both hands freely and can move from the floor to standing without adult assistance and needs to hold the handrail when going up or down stairs and is not yet able to run and jump
validValue.description: Can walk on their own without using a walking aid, but has difficulty walking long distances or on uneven surfaces and can sit in a normal adult chair and use both hands freely and can move from the floor to standing without adult assistance and needs to hold the handrail when going up or down stairs and is not yet able to run and jump

validValue.meaningText: Can walk on their own without using a walking aid, including fairly long distances, outdoors and on uneven surfaces and can move from the floor or a chair to standing without using their hands for support and can go up and down stairs without needing to hold the handrail and is beginning to run and jump
validValue.description: Can walk on their own without using a walking aid, including fairly long distances, outdoors and on uneven surfaces and can move from the floor or a chair to standing without using their hands for support and can go up and down stairs without needing to hold the handrail and is beginning to run and jump

protocol.preferredDefinition: The Gross Motor Function Classification System (GMFCS) Family Report Questionnaire is a five item parent-report instrument that classifies children with cerebral palsy based on current motor ability including the need for assistive technology.

form.longName: PhenX PX131203 - Gross Motor Function 612 Years Old
form.preferredDefinition: The Gross Motor Function Classification System (GMFCS) Family Report Questionnaire is a five item parent-report instrument that classifies children with cerebral palsy based on current motor ability including the need for assistive technology.

question.questionText: My child... (pxt131203_gross_motor_function)

validValue.meaningText: Has difficulty sitting on their own and controlling their head and body posture in most positions and has difficulty achieving any voluntary control of movement and needs a specially supportive chair to sit comfortably and has to be lifted or hoisted by another person to move
validValue.description: Has difficulty sitting on their own and controlling their head and body posture in most positions and has difficulty achieving any voluntary control of movement and needs a specially supportive chair to sit comfortably and has to be lifted or hoisted by another person to move

validValue.meaningText: Can sit on their own but does not stand or walk without significant support and therefore relies mostly on wheelchair at home, school and in the community and often needs extra body / trunk support to improve arm and hand function and may achieve self-mobility using a powered wheelchair
validValue.description: Can sit on their own but does not stand or walk without significant support and therefore relies mostly on wheelchair at home, school and in the community and often needs extra body / trunk support to improve arm and hand function and may achieve self-mobility using a powered wheelchair

validValue.meaningText: Can stand on their own and only walks using a walking aid (such as a walker, rollator, crutches, canes, etc.) and finds it difficult to climb stairs, or walk on uneven surfaces and may use a wheelchair when travelling for long distances or in crowds
validValue.description: Can stand on their own and only walks using a walking aid (such as a walker, rollator, crutches, canes, etc.) and finds it difficult to climb stairs, or walk on uneven surfaces and may use a wheelchair when travelling for long distances or in crowds

validValue.meaningText: Can walk on their own without using walking aids, but needs to hold the handrail when going up or down stairs and often finds it difficult to walk on uneven surfaces, slopes or in crowds
validValue.description: Can walk on their own without using walking aids, but needs to hold the handrail when going up or down stairs and often finds it difficult to walk on uneven surfaces, slopes or in crowds

validValue.meaningText: Can walk on their own without using walking aids, and can go up or down stairs without needing to hold the handrail and walks wherever they want to go (including uneven surfaces, slopes or in crowds) and can run and jump although their speed, balance, and coordination may be slightly limited
validValue.description: Can walk on their own without using walking aids, and can go up or down stairs without needing to hold the handrail and walks wherever they want to go (including uneven surfaces, slopes or in crowds) and can run and jump although their speed, balance, and coordination may be slightly limited

form.longName: PhenX PX131301 - Signs Of Essential Tremor
form.preferredDefinition: The Washington Heights-Inwood Genetic Study of Essential Tremor (WHIGET) Tremor Rating Scale is a 23-item videotaped examination that assesses rest, postural, and kinetic tremor severity. Rated tasks include arm extension, pouring water between cups, drinking from a spoon, drinking from a cup, drawing Archimedes spirals, and touching a finger to the nose. The protocol includes scoring and classification instructions. A teaching videotape is also available to aid in training raters.

validValue.description: low-amplitude/barely perceivable tremor or intermittent tremor

validValue.meaningText: tremor is of moderate amplitude (1-2 cm) and usually present; it is clearly oscillatory
validValue.description: tremor is of moderate amplitude (1-2 cm) and usually present; it is clearly oscillatory

validValue.meaningText: large-amplitude (>2 cm), violent, jerky tremor resulting in difficulty completing the task due to spilling or inability to hold a pen to paper

question.questionText: While the subject is standing, please observe: (instructions_stand_131301)
Hands hanging at sides for 10 s videotape legs too (hands_hanging_at_side)
Walking 20 ft and turning (walking_twenty_feet)
Tandem gait for 10 steps (pxt131301_gait)
Dominant Hand (dominant_hand)

Scoring: Criteria for ET: 1. On examination, a +2 postural tremor of at least 1 arm (a head tremor may also be present, but is insufficient for the diagnosis) 2. On examination, there must be a. a +2 kinetic tremor during at least 4 tasks or b. a +2 kinetic tremor on 1 task and a +3 kinetic tremor on a second task; tasks include: pouring water, using a spoon to drink water, drinking water, finger-to-nose, and drawing a spiral 3. If on examination the tremor is present in the dominant hand, then by report it must interfere with at least 1 activity of daily living (eating, drinking, writing, use of hands); if on examination, the tremor is not present in the dominant hand, this criterion is irrelevant. 4. Medications, hyperthyroidism, alcohol, or dystonia are not potential etiologic factors 5. Not psychogenic (bizarre features, inconsistent in character, changing, subject is distractable, other psychiatric features on examination) Criteria for probable ET (1 and 3-5 must be true; also, either 2a or 2b must be true): 1. On examination, a +2 postural tremor of arms may or may not be present 2. (a) Same as 2 above (b) Head tremor is present on examination 3. Tremor in the dominant hand may or may not interfere with at least 1 daily activity 4. Medications, hyperthyroidism, dystonia, or alcohol are not potential etiologic factors 5. Not psychogenic Criteria for possible ET: 1. On examination, a +2 kinetic tremor must be present on 3 tasks 2. No other stipulations Tremor Ratings (0 to +3): 0 = no visible tremor +1 = low-amplitude/barely perceivable tremor or intermittent tremor +2 = tremor is of moderate amplitude (1-2 cm) and usually present; it is clearly oscillatory +3 = large-amplitude (>2 cm), violent, jerky tremor resulting in difficulty completing the task due to spilling or inability to hold a pen to paper Note from the Neurology Working Group: Please see Louis et al. (2001) for discus..TRUNCATED(scoring_131301)

protocol.preferredDefinition: The Washington Heights-Inwood Genetic Study of Essential Tremor (WHIGET) Tremor Rating Scale is a 23-item videotaped examination that assesses rest, postural, and kinetic tremor severity. Rated tasks include arm extension, pouring water between cups, drinking from a spoon, drinking from a cup, drawing Archimedes spirals, and touching a finger to the nose. The protocol includes scoring and classification instructions. A teaching videotape is also available to aid in training raters.
